gsDesign2KeyFunctionsInnerLogic 1.0.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    ahr: computes AHR under NPH assumptions and (stratified) populations expected_accrual: computes the expected cumulative enrollment (accrual) given a set of piecewise constant enrollment rates and times expected_event: compute expected number of events at 1 time point expected_time: compute time when a targeted number of events is made fixed_design_*: compute sample size/power of a fixed design gs_b: specify fixed boundaries in group sequential designs gs_info_ahr: compute statistical information by the AHR method gs_power_npe: derives bounds and crossing probabilities for group sequential designs under NPH assumptions Computing spending boundaries in group sequential design summary & as_gt: summarize group sequential design

    fixed_design_*: compute sample size/power of a fixed design

    Yujie Zhao

    usage-fixed-design.Rmd
    library(gt)
library(gsDesign)
library(gsDesign2)
library(dplyr)

    Introduction

    In this vignette, we introduce the key functionality of fixed_design_xxx() in gsDesign2. Generally speaking, fixed_design_xxx() is capable of both power calculations and sample size calculations under many methods, including

    • fixed_design_ahr(): AHR
    • fixed_design_fh()Fleming-Harrington (FH) (farrington1990test?)
    • fixed_design_mb()Magirr-Burman (MB)
    • fixed_design_lf()Lachin-Foulkes (LF) (lachin1986evaluation?)
    • fixed_design_rmst()RMST (yung2020sample?)
    • fixed_design_milestone()Milestone (yung2020sample?)
    • fixed_design_rd()Risk difference (RD) (mehrotra2000minimum?).

    Throughout this vignette, we assume the design parameter is

    # Enrollment rate
enroll_rate <- define_enroll_rate(
  duration = 18,
  rate = 20
)

# Failure rates
fail_rate <- define_fail_rate(
  duration = c(4, 100),
  fail_rate = log(2) / 12,
  hr = c(1, .6),
  dropout_rate = .001
)

# Study duration in months
study_duration <- 36

# Experimental / Control randomization ratio
ratio <- 1

# 1-sided Type I error
alpha <- 0.025
# Type II error (1 - power)
beta <- 0.1

    Examples of AHR

    If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

    fixed_design_ahr(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under AHR Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Average hazard ratio 463.078 324.7077 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Power computed with average hazard ratio method.

    Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of AHR by

    fixed_design_ahr(
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under AHR Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Average hazard ratio 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.815886
    1 Power computed with average hazard ratio method.

    Examples of FH

    If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

    # Fixed design with a given power with default rho/gamma
fixed_design_fh(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Fleming-Harrington Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Fleming-Harrington FH(0, 0) (logrank) 458.3509 321.3931 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Power for Fleming-Harrington test FH(0, 0) (logrank) using method of Yung and Liu.

    In the above example, the FH parameters (rho, gamma) take the default value as rho = 0, gamma = 0.5. But users can always custom their rho and gamma by

    # Fixed design with a given power with input rho/gamma
fixed_design_fh(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  rho = 0.5,
  gamma = 0.5
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Fleming-Harrington Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Fleming-Harrington FH(0.5, 0.5) 376.0673 263.6963 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Power for Fleming-Harrington test FH(0.5, 0.5) using method of Yung and Liu.

    Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of FH under the default rho, gamma by

    # Fixed design with power calculated
fixed_design_fh(
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Fleming-Harrington Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Fleming-Harrington FH(0, 0) (logrank) 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8200818
    1 Power for Fleming-Harrington test FH(0, 0) (logrank) using method of Yung and Liu.

    But users can always custom their rho and gamma by

    # Fixed design with power calculated
fixed_design_fh(
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  rho = 0.5, gamma = 0.5
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Fleming-Harrington Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Fleming-Harrington FH(0.5, 0.5) 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8872751
    1 Power for Fleming-Harrington test FH(0.5, 0.5) using method of Yung and Liu.

    Examples of mb

    If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

    fixed_design_mb(
  ratio = ratio,
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Magirr-Burman Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Modestly weighted LR: tau = 6 412.2826 289.0902 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Power for Modestly weighted LR: tau = 6 computed with method of Yung and Liu.

    In the above example, the mb parameter (tau) takes the default value as tau = 6. But users can always custom their tau by

    fixed_design_mb(
  ratio = ratio,
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  tau = 4
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Magirr-Burman Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Modestly weighted LR: tau = 4 429.7777 301.3577 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Power for Modestly weighted LR: tau = 4 computed with method of Yung and Liu.

    Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of MB under the default tau = 6 by

    fixed_design_mb(
  ratio = ratio,
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Magirr-Burman Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Modestly weighted LR: tau = 6 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8579005
    1 Power for Modestly weighted LR: tau = 6 computed with method of Yung and Liu.

    But users can always custom their tau by

    fixed_design_mb(
  ratio = ratio,
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  tau = 4
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Magirr-Burman Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Modestly weighted LR: tau = 4 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8435226
    1 Power for Modestly weighted LR: tau = 4 computed with method of Yung and Liu.

    Examples of lf

    If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

    fixed_design_lf(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Lachin and Foulkes Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Lachin and Foulkes 453.1714 321.8553 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Power using Lachin and Foulkes method applied using expected average hazard ratio (AHR) at time of planned analysis.

    Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of LF by

    fixed_design_lf(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Lachin and Foulkes Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Lachin and Foulkes 360 255.6823 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8240862
    1 Power using Lachin and Foulkes method applied using expected average hazard ratio (AHR) at time of planned analysis.

    Examples of MaxCombo

    If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

    fixed_design_maxcombo(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under MaxCombo Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    MaxCombo: logrank, FH(0, 1), FH(1, 0) 342.648 240.2629 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9000027
    1 Power for MaxCombo test with Fleming-Harrington tests: logrank, FH(0, 1), FH(1, 0).

    In the above example, the MaxCombo parameters take the default value

    data.frame(rho = c(0, 0), gamma = c(0, 0.5), tau = -1) %>% gt()
    rho gamma tau
    0 0.0 -1
    0 0.5 -1

    But users can always custom their rho, gamma, tau by

    fixed_design_maxcombo(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  rho = c(0, 0.5, 0.5),
  gamma = c(0, 0, 0.5),
  tau = c(-1, 4, 6)
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under MaxCombo Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    MaxCombo: logrank, FH(0.5, 0), FH(0.5, 0.5) 374.9891 262.9403 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9000001
    1 Power for MaxCombo test with Fleming-Harrington tests: logrank, FH(0.5, 0), FH(0.5, 0.5).

    Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of MaxCombo under the default parameters by

    fixed_design_maxcombo(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under MaxCombo Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    MaxCombo: logrank, FH(0, 1), FH(1, 0) 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9128422
    1 Power for MaxCombo test with Fleming-Harrington tests: logrank, FH(0, 1), FH(1, 0).

    But users can always custom their rho, gamma, tau by

    fixed_design_maxcombo(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  rho = c(0, 0.5, 0.5),
  gamma = c(0, 0, 0.5),
  tau = c(-1, 4, 6)
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under MaxCombo Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    MaxCombo: logrank, FH(0.5, 0), FH(0.5, 0.5) 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8883467
    1 Power for MaxCombo test with Fleming-Harrington tests: logrank, FH(0.5, 0), FH(0.5, 0.5).

    Examples of RMST

    If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

    fixed_design_rmst(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  tau = 18
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Restricted Mean Survival Time Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    RMST: tau = 18 1298.358 910.4017 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Power for RMST: tau = 18 computed with method of Yung and Liu.

    Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of RMST by

    fixed_design_rmst(
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  tau = 18
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Restricted Mean Survival Time Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    RMST: tau = 18 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.4001002
    1 Power for RMST: tau = 18 computed with method of Yung and Liu.

    Examples of Milestone

    If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

    fixed_design_milestone(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  tau = 18
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Milestone Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Milestone: tau = 18 556.9044 390.4983 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Power for Milestone: tau = 18 computed with method of Yung and Liu.

    Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of Milestone by

    fixed_design_milestone(
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  tau = 18
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design under Milestone Method1
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Milestone: tau = 18 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.7409392
    1 Power for Milestone: tau = 18 computed with method of Yung and Liu.

    Examples of RD

    If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

    fixed_design_rd(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  p_c = .15,
  p_e = .1,
  rd0 = 0,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design of Risk Difference under Farrington-Manning Method1
    Design N Bound alpha Power
    Risk difference 1845.185 1.959964 0.025 0.9
    1 Risk difference power without continuity correction using method of Farrington and Manning.

    Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power by

    fixed_design_rd(
  alpha = alpha,
  power = NULL,
  p_c = .15,
  p_e = .1,
  rd0 = 0,
  n = 2000,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
    Fixed Design of Risk Difference under Farrington-Manning Method1
    Design N Bound alpha Power
    Risk difference 2000 1.959964 0.025 0.9228823
    1 Risk difference power without continuity correction using method of Farrington and Manning.

    Examples to get multiple designs together 

    x_ahr <- fixed_design_ahr(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
)

x_fh <- fixed_design_fh(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  rho = 0.5,
  gamma = 0.5
)

x_mb <- fixed_design_mb(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  tau = 4
)

x_lf <- fixed_design_lf(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
)

x_maxcombo <- fixed_design_maxcombo(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  rho = c(0, 0.5, 0.5),
  gamma = c(0, 0, 0.5),
  tau = c(-1, 4, 6)
)

x_rmst <- fixed_design_rmst(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  tau = 30
)

x_milestone <- fixed_design_milestone(
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  tau = 30
)

rbind(
  summary(x_ahr), summary(x_fh),
  summary(x_mb), summary(x_lf),
  summary(x_maxcombo), summary(x_rmst),
  summary(x_milestone)
) %>% gt()
    Design N Events Time Bound alpha Power
    Average hazard ratio 360 252.4300 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8158860
    Fleming-Harrington FH(0.5, 0.5) 360 252.4300 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8872751
    Modestly weighted LR: tau = 4 360 252.4300 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8435226
    Lachin and Foulkes 360 255.6823 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8240862
    MaxCombo: logrank, FH(0.5, 0), FH(0.5, 0.5) 360 252.4300 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8883464
    RMST: tau = 30 360 252.4300 36 1.959964 0.025 0.7149430
    Milestone: tau = 30 360 252.4300 36 1.959964 0.025 0.7737853
